CCDM 30.6.1.2.3, Electronic Mail and Messaging, is revised to reﬂect updated IRM references and messaging technology available to Chief Counsel employees, as well as a new section (4) setting forth encryption requirements for sending email messages or attachments to recipients outside the
CCDM 30.6.1 - updated the links and references throughout the document.
This section supersedes CCDM 30.6.1.2.3, Electronic Mail and Messaging, dated October 5, 2016..

) This section establishes policies and guidelines for the security of documents, personnel, and property in the Office of Chief Counsel. Guidelines (

) Security management and procedures will be determined by the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance & Management) in his/her role as the Designated crediting Authority (DAA), using the following as guidance after taking into account the risks and needs of the Office of Chief Counsel: • The Privacy Act of
• Federal Information Security Management Act (FISMA) of
• OMB Circulars A-
and A-
• Treasury IT Security Program, TDP
• Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) • Public Law
) Additionally, such procedures will be consistent with the provisions of IRC sections
and

) Employees are responsible for the protection and proper disposition of all mation, documents and property in their possession or control. They must Information, make every effort to protect information, documents and other property and entrusted to their care and prevent unauthorized entry into areas where the information, documents and property are located. (

) The guidelines included in this section are applicable to employees working ﬂexiplace locations. Files containing IRS information or data will be when not in use or in the possession of the employee. (
) For guidelines concerning Chief Counsel and IRS information systems, employees should consult their servicing MITS organization or IRM
, formation Technology (IT) Security Policy and Guidance. (

) The responsibilities of managers are to: • Support safety and security programs and policies • Ensure adequate training of personnel in safety and security (e.g., drills) • Discuss safety and security procedures with employees at least annually • Ensure security measures are followed to protect life, information, ties, and property within their areas (

) The responsibilities of employees are to: • Support safety and security programs and policies • Report accidents or incidents promptly • Assist in the investigation and removal of hazards • Be alert to strangers or suspicious packages in the work area

) Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) information is deﬁned as any information requires protection due to the risk and magnitude of loss or harm to the IRS of Conﬁdential the privacy to which individuals are entitled under
a (the Official Privacy Act), which could result from unintentional or deliberate disclosure, al- and Tax teration or destruction. (

) SBU shall be the primary term used to mark sensitive but unclassiﬁed tion originating within Chief Counsel offices. The SBU designation identiﬁes information that, if released, could cause harm to a person’s privacy or adversely impact economic, industrial, or international ﬁnancial institutions; or compromise unclassiﬁed programs, essential operations or critical infrastruc- tures. The “Official Use Only” and “Limited Official Use” designations, which are solely used to prevent the automatic distribution to the public of printed materials, should not be routinely used to identify SBU information contained Office of Chief Counsel documents. For assistance in these matters, contact Branch
or

of the office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure & Ad- ministration). Note: Although information that would be required to be disclosed under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) generally should not meet the criteria for SBU designation, simply because information bears the SBU designation does not mean it is automatically exempt from the FOIA. SBU information that becomes the subject of a FOIA request must be evaluated to determine in each instance whether one or more FOIA exemptions apply. (

) SBU information is categorized in one or more of the following groups: • Tax data (e.g. tax returns, returns information, and taxpayer • Law enforcement information (e.g., grand jury, informant, and under- cover operations information) • Proprietary information (e.g., contracts, solicitations, information by the Trade Secrets Act, the Procurement Integrity Act, and similar statues) • Employee Information (e.g., personnel, payroll, and evaluation data) • Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) (i.e., all taxpayer information or any combination of information that can be used to uniquely identify, contact, or locate a person) Note: The Privacy Act of
U.S.C. §
a, provides statutory recognition of an individual’s right to privacy. For example, the Privacy Act protects tion which is retrieved by reference to a name or other personal identiﬁer,

Although information that would be required to be disclosed under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) generally should not meet the criteria for SBU designation, simply because information bears the SBU designation does not mean it is automatically exempt from the FOIA. SBU information that becomes the subject of a FOIA request must be evaluated to determine in each instance whether one or more FOIA exemptions apply.
Tax data (e.g. tax returns, returns information, and taxpayer information) Law enforcement information (e.g., grand jury, informant, and under

cover operations information) Proprietary information (e.g., contracts, solicitations, information covered by the Trade Secrets Act, the Procurement Integrity Act, and similar statues) Employee Information (e.g., personnel, payroll, and evaluation data) Personally Identiﬁable Information (PII) (i.e., all taxpayer information or any combination of information that can be used to uniquely identify, contact, or locate a person)
Note: The Privacy Act of
U.S.C. §

a, provides statutory recognition of an individual’s right to privacy. For example, the Privacy Act protects informa- tion which is retrieved by reference to a name or other personal identiﬁer, such as a social security number or SEID. (
) All employees who have had access to tax data or privacy information are pro- hibited from disclosing such information except as authorized by law (and implementing regulations); see IRM

, Disclosure of Official Information (various chapters). Employees should safeguard SBU information in order to avoid the loss or the unauthorized disclosure or destruction of ﬁles, irrespective of the format in which it is maintained (e.g., paper, electronic, or other media). (

) Standard practice is to maintain SBU ﬁles and documents in locked cabinets or compartments (e.g., desk drawers, overhead bins) during nonworking hours and during periods when the work area is vacant. The records may also be stored in a room with physical access control measures that prevent unauthor- ized access by the public, visitors, or other persons without a need-to-know.
Security of Conﬁdential Information, Official Documents, Tax Data, Personnel and Property 30.6.1 page 3
Examples of acceptable access control measures include, but ar not limited to, a locked room (both key or cipher locks) or a restricted-access work area con- trolled by a card reader.

a. Employees should store all electronic records containing SBU/PII on Chief Counsel network. b. All SBU/PII that is processed, stored, or transmitted by computer equipment (such as laptops and memory storage devices) outside of facilities must be encrypted. Employees should use measures appropriate to the circumstances to protect SBU information on desks, on workstations or in conference or other work rooms when they are not present during the workday, in order to prevent thorized access. Employees should immediately report allegations or information regarding authorized disclosure of tax data or privacy information to their manager for referral to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) Additional information is available in: • CCDM

) Within the Office of Chief Counsel, documents may be classiﬁed Official Use Only (OUO) by the persons authorized in Delegation Order No.
, tive Control of Documents and Material, as revised (see IRM
, Delegations of Authority for Communications, Liaison and Disclosure This classiﬁcation is used for documents which may be made available only authorized personnel. (

) The overall principle is that the greatest amount of information will be made available to the public whenever possible. The OUO classiﬁcation will be used only for law enforcement matters if publication would hinder the law enforcement process. OUO classiﬁcation is generally invoked word by word line by line, so that only the speciﬁc words or lines that need to be classiﬁed are in fact classiﬁed. (

) The classiﬁcation of materials as Official Use Only requires the concurrence the office of the Director, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure, and shall be coordinated by the Deputy Associate Chief Counsel (Legislation and Policy).

tive Control of Documents and Material, as revised (see IRM

, Delegations of Authority for Communications, Liaison and Disclosure Activities). This classiﬁcation is used for documents which may be made available only to authorized personnel. The overall principle is that the greatest amount of information will be made available to the public whenever possible. The OUO classiﬁcation will generally be used only for law enforcement matters if publication would hinder the law enforcement process. OUO classiﬁcation is generally invoked word by word or line by line, so that only the speciﬁc words or lines that need to be classiﬁed are in fact classiﬁed. The classiﬁcation of materials as Official Use Only requires the concurrence of the office of the Director, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure, and shall be coordinated by the Deputy Associate Chief Counsel (Legislation and Policy).
30.6 Security and Emergency Preparedness
Security and Emergency (
) For additional guidance on use of the Official Use Only classiﬁcation, see
, Designation of Documents. (

) All Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) documents and documents classiﬁed ″Official Use Only″ (OUO) must be placed in a designated container for of SBU and disposal, separate from wastepaper baskets or paper recycling receptacles. (
) In the Headquarters Office, each Administrative Officer will establish a point in the office for collection and proper disposal of SBU and OUO tion. (
) In ﬁeld offices, each Finance and Management (F&M) Office Manager is re- sponsible for establishing procedures for the proper disposal of SBU and information. (
) Electronic mail (email) is provided for official business purposes. (

) Employees should evaluate the propriety of email as the communication Mail and vehicle for particular information or work products. If there is doubt as to whether email is appropriate, employees should check with their manager. Guidance on the use of email may be found in IRM
, Standards for ing EMail, and in IRM
, Privacy and Information Protection, Privacy Policy, Email. (
) Where appropriate, Enterprise Remote Access Protocol (ERAP) and must be used for email to IRS employees. (

) Email messages or email attachments to recipients outside the IRS that contain PII or taxpayer information must be encrypted, using an encryption method. If the email is to a taxpayer or taxpayer representative, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) in which the taxpayer acknowledges the risks of using email must be executed prior to sending any such email. MOU form differs depending on the type of encryption used. The procedures for sending encrypted email to recipients outside the IRS and the appropriate MOU forms may be found on the Litigation Technology Page of the Chief Counsel Intranet. Chief Counsel’s use of encrypted email in communications with taxpayers or taxpayer representatives in connection with Tax Court tion, letter rulings or closing agreements is an authorized secure email program under IRM

) Routing and review procedures for email are the same as for letters and memoranda. Unless otherwise requested or unless simultaneous review is necessary, work products should be sent to the addressee(s) through customary supervisory/review channels. (

) ″Broadcast/All User″ email messages should receive pre-authorization in the headquarters office by an Associate Chief Counsel. In ﬁeld offices, ″All User″ messages should be approved by the Area Counsel; cross-functional messages should be approved by the Managing Counsel or F&M Area Manager. ″All User″ email messages should include the name and title of the authorizing official. (

) Microsoft Skype and Lync are Microsoft messaging applications that facilitate informal, unofficial communication between employees. Chief Counsel has made an institutional decision to not conduct official business via Skype or Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

30.6.1.2.3 (03-27-2020) Electronic Mail and Messaging
) Where appropriate, Enterprise Remote Access Protocol (ERAP) and must be used for email to IRS employees. (

) Email messages or email attachments to recipients outside the IRS that contain PII or taxpayer information must be encrypted, using an IRS-approved encryption method. If the email is to a taxpayer or taxpayer representative, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) in which the taxpayer acknowledges the risks of using email must be executed prior to sending any such email. MOU form differs depending on the type of encryption used. The procedures for sending encrypted email to recipients outside the IRS and the appropriate MOU forms may be found on the Litigation Technology Page of the Chief Counsel Intranet. Chief Counsel’s use of encrypted email in communications with taxpayers or taxpayer representatives in connection with Tax Court litiga- tion, letter rulings or closing agreements is an authorized secure email program under IRM

) Routing and review procedures for email are the same as for letters and memoranda. Unless otherwise requested or unless simultaneous review is necessary, work products should be sent to the addressee(s) through customary supervisory/review channels. (

) ″Broadcast/All User″ email messages should receive pre-authorization in the headquarters office by an Associate Chief Counsel. In ﬁeld offices, ″All User″ messages should be approved by the Area Counsel; cross-functional messages should be approved by the Managing Counsel or F&M Area Manager. ″All User″ email messages should include the name and title of the authorizing official. (

) Microsoft Skype and Lync are Microsoft messaging applications that facilitate informal, unofficial communication between employees. Chief Counsel has made an institutional decision to not conduct official business via Skype or
Security of Conﬁdential Information, Official Documents, Tax Data, Personnel and Property 30.6.1 page

Lync, or other non-email messaging applications, including text messaging. Outlook is not conﬁgured to automatically save Skype and Lync tions. If a conversation in Skype, Lync, or any other messaging application rises to the level of official business, the Chief Counsel user must take priate measures to preserve the conversation. Documents shared via Skype and Lync retain the status such documents had when originally created, and the appropriate document retention policies and discovery obligations applicable to those documents. Security and Emergency (

) The Office of Chief Counsel is committed to providing for the security of its employees and will seek to minimize or eliminate safety hazards and to encourage safe practices. Further information can be found in the following: • IRM
, Authorized ID Media • IRM
, Identiﬁcation Card • IRM
, Occupational Safety and Health Program (
) The Office of Chief Counsel will follow the guidelines established by IRS, partment of the Treasury, GSA, and the Department of Homeland Security. (

) Employees should ensure that information, documents and property to them are secured. Those who are in private offices have the locking doors when leaving their work areas. Employees should keep valuables in their possession. (
) Employees are responsible for preventing unauthorized entry into areas government information, documents and property are located. (
) At the close of business, managers should ensure that doors leading into areas under their control and supervision are locked. (
) Employees should immediately report burglary, robbery, or theft of or personal property to their manager and to the servicing Security Office. thefts, no matter how small, should be reported. (

) Employees are responsible for the security of pocket commissions, ID (badges) and other types of identiﬁcation media issued to them. Media media should be in the possession of employees and should never be left attended in briefcases, unlocked desk drawers, vehicles, etc. When not in they should be stored in a locked container or left with a manager. (
) Employees will display ID cards at all times while in IRS facilities. (

) Employees must immediately report the loss, theft or destruction of tion media through their manager to the servicing Security office. The should explain the circumstances and describe the recovery attempts (
) The recovery of any type of identiﬁcation media should be reported through channels to the issuing Security office. (

) The policy of the Office of Chief Counsel is to provide reasonable commensurate with the nature and value of the information or property involved. Protective measures will vary by location, function and facility. (
) In general, access to space, property and the information contained therein be restricted to those with a need for access. (
) For Counsel-speciﬁc guidelines, see CCDM
, Space, Property, ment, and Telecommunications. (
) For IRS access and protection standards, see: • IRM
, Methods of Providing Protection • IRM
, Minimum Protection Standards Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
D
30.6 Security and Emergency Preparedness
The Office of Chief Counsel will follow the guidelines established by IRS, De- partment of the Treasury, GSA, and the Department of Homeland Security.
Employees are responsible for preventing unauthorized entry into areas government information, documents and property are located.
At the close of business, managers should ensure that doors leading into areas under their control and supervision are locked.
Security of Conﬁdential Information, Official Documents, Tax Data, Personnel and Property 30.6.1 page
) Where feasible, reception areas will be provided. Conference rooms and areas expected to be used by visitors will be placed near entrances and from secured or restricted areas. (
) Employees will be required to sign a receipt for door keys, building keys electronic access cards issued to them. Under no circumstances should be duplicated by employees. (

) Employees are responsible for reporting the loss of keys or access cards the Administrative Officer (employees located in Headquarters offices) or Office Manager (ﬁeld offices). The Administrative Officer or Office Manager responsible for reporting key reassignments and losses to the local IRS Security office. (

) Codes for combination locks and key pads should be changed: • At least once every six months • When anyone with the current combination leaves or is terminated • When an attempt to compromise the combination is made (
) Keyed locks should be changed periodically as the budget permits. (
) Electronic access cards, door keys and building keys must be returned employees resign, retire, are reassigned to another office, or are (

) In response to various incidents in the US Postal Service (USPS) system, Counsel mail, regardless of the source or method of delivery (e.g., delivery services), will be opened prior to delivery. The only exceptions are bulk mail and mail that has been irradiated by USPS. Deliveries should be made to the area speciﬁed by the Agency-Wide Shared Services (AWSS) resentative for the building. (
) Employees opening mail should take appropriate precautions; protective supplies will be provided by IRS or Counsel. (

) Office Managers and headquarters Administrative Officers should post guidelines for processing mail and packages in the mail area, phone numbers for appropriate Security personnel. They may obtain information from their servicing Security office. (

) Employees should be alert to suspicious packages which may: • Appear unusual • Carry excessive postage • Display restrictive endorsements such as “Personal” or • Contain misspelled or misidentiﬁed names, titles, addresses or zations • Be unexpected mail from a foreign country (

) If a suspicious package is discovered, employees should not handle the package or remove any items from the area. They should leave the area, gently close the door, and contact their manager. If a biochemical suspected, the employee should immediately contact the Security office follow their direction. Chief Counsel Directives Manual
Where feasible, reception areas will be provided. Conference rooms and other areas expected to be used by visitors will be placed near entrances and away from secured or restricted areas.
locks should be changed periodically as the budget
Electronic access cards, door keys and building keys must be returned when employees resign, retire, are reassigned to another office, or are terminated.

Security and Emergency Preparedness
) The current USPS procedures in response to anthrax threats may cause delays in sending mail to the Tax Court, Department of Justice, or other Delays Federal offices in the Washington, D.C. area. (

) Employees should be aware of possible delays and should consider whether overnight delivery or some form of electronic transmission (fax or email) is a suitable alternative if the material is truly time sensitive. (
) Procedures for addressing legal issues resulting from delays in mail destined for the Tax Court are covered in more detail in CCDM Part
Procedures for addressing legal issues resulting from delays in mail destined for the Tax Court are covered in more detail in CCDM Part 35.
